xxl.cursors
Class Grouper

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.Grouper
public class Grouper
extends Object
implements Cursor

A Grouper partitions input data into groups (lazy evaluation).
A predicate (or Boolean-Function) is used to compare the current element with the last element. If the predicate returns true a new group starts. A call to next returns a Cursor pointing to the next group.

Note: The given Iterators and PeekIterators are wrapped to Cursors. The (Boolean-)function specified in a constructor is internally wrapped to a predicate.

Example usage: 

 	Grouper grouper = new Grouper(
 		new RandomIntegers(100,50),
 			new Predicate () { // the predicate used for comparison
 				public boolean invoke (Object previous, Object next) {
 					return ((Integer)previous).intValue() > ((Integer)next).intValue();
 				}
 			}
 	);
 	while(grouper.hasNext()) {
 		Cursor sequence = (Cursor)grouper.next(); // a cursors pointing to the next group
 		while(sequence.hasNext())
 			System.out.print(sequence.next()+"; ");
 		System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
 	}
 	grouper.close();
This example partitions 50 random integers with maximum value 99 into groups. A new group is started when the predicate returns true, that is the case when the next integer is lower than the previous integer.
So this instance of a Grouper returns all monotonous ascending sequences contained in the RandomIntegers-Cursor by lazy evaluation.

See Also:
Cursor, Function, Predicate, Iterator

Method Detail

close

public void close()
Closes the Grouper. Signals the Grouper to cleanup resources, close files, etc.
After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results.
Multiple calls to close() do not have any effect, i.e. if close() was called the Grouper remains in the state "closed".
Specified by:
close in interface Cursor

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
This happens when the specified predicate evalutated for the previous element and the next element of the cursor, determined by cursor.peek() is true. Then a new group starts.
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the Grouper has more elements, otherwise false.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration (a Cursor).
In this case that means the next group of elements that are equal concerning the user-defined predicate is returned as a new Cursor.
Important: LAZY EVALUATION is used!
With the help of this Cursor-object the caller is able to traverse and operate with the group of elements. The delivered cursor does definitely not support the methods close and reset.
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration, a new Cursor.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This operation is not supported by Groupers, therefore an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by the Grouper.

remove

public void remove()
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This operation is not supported by Groupers, therefore an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the Grouper.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the Grouper to its initial state. (optional operation)
That means the reset method of the input-Cursor is called and the group-size is set to 0.
So the caller is able to traverse the underlying collection again.
Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by the input-Cursor.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns false because Groupers do not support the peek- operation.
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor
Returns:
false if the peek operation is not supported by the Grouper, otherwise true.

update

public void update(Object object)
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This operation is not supported by Groupers, therefore an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
update in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the Grouper.
